text:
(1) Main Ave., adjoining the N.W. corner of Vernon Boulevard, showing the Rapelje Mansion, erected in 1780 by Jacobus Riker at 29 Main Street (old number). This house was occupied by the family for over a hundred years. It was still standing in October 1934.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2) The same, showing the west side of the house.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3) The same, showing also the front of the house facing on Main Ave.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(4) The same, showing the east side of the house.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Main Avenue, foreground, at the S.W. corner of Welling Court, showing in a set of four views the S. A. Halsey house of 1873. It was demolished in 1928. Hendrick Suydam, a farmer of Bedford, bought the estate of William Lawrence, deceased, in 1794. Between 1825 and 1852 when S. A. Halsey purchased it, it was owned by one Whitfield. Before S. A. Halsey purchased it and made it his home, it had been a roadhouse at which he often stopped. This individual in 1849 purchased several farms at Astoria and laid out and opened Broadway, The Crescent, Emerald Street, Academy Street, Grand Street, First Ave., Second Ave., and Jamaica Ave. At about 1840 he purchased the Horn Hook Ferry running to 86th Street, New York City, which he operated for 30 years. Peter Fitzsimmons was the first operator of this line. This individual also conducted in 1782 a tavern at the house of the widow Betts at Halletts Cove. This was the house of Grant Thorburn in 1852.

May 1923.
Views 2,364: 1922.

Eugene L. Ambruster Collection.

title: Queens: Main Avenue - Park Row

text:
(1) Main Ave., adjoining the N.W. corner of Vernon Boulevard, showing the Rapelye Mansion. There is a dispute as to its identity. Eugene L. Armbruster states it is the Cornelius Rapelye house; one Van Rieper states it to be the Tavern; another, Mr. Roe S. Johnson states that this was the Trafford house and was also used as a tavern. Eugene L. Armbruster's history on this subject is that John Trafford married Grace Rapelye, sister of C. Rapelye, who erected this house in 1780. It was occupied by C. R. Trafford in 1873.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection. April 1925.

(2) The same, viewed eastward.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection. April 1925.

Eugene L. Armbruster's history on this subject is that John Trafford married Grace Rapelye, sister of C. Rapelye, who erected this house in 1780. It was occupied by C. R. Trafford in 1873.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection. April 1925.
